how would you describe your main use cas: Note-taking;Journalling;Task and project management (including CRMs);As a knowledge base (including technical, non-fiction and encyclopaedic content)
do you share your tiddlywiki(s) with oth: No, but I may export content into other formats and share individual tiddlers, the whole wiki, or an extract of the wiki
putting it all together, what value does: It is flexible to make any database I need for personal use. For example, I track every piece of media I consume for example, and I prefer having it locally. I know I can always depend on TiddlyWiki, and I find it helpful to follow link to link, which TiddlyWiki makes v. natural.

how do you save changes in tiddlywiki?: Single-file wiki through web browser with Download Saver (default saving mechanism);Single-file wiki with TiddlyDesktop;Single-file wiki third-party mobile app (e.g. Tiddloid, Quine)

outside of plugins, palettes and other i: I often make special-purpose buttons to create tiddlers, which I tend to put in the sidebar. I just have one template I clone for that purpose. I have MediaWiki-style infobox fores my databases that I cribbed from the Kansas Railroads wiki.
what are we doing well? prompts for thin:
Remaining a unique proposition in being software that truly is local-first and often local-only, as well as being able to run anywhere with basically no effort whatsoever.

Being a community of people who really care and think about why they use software. More importantly, people that really think out of the box. I have used a lot of geeky 'productivity' software, mostly from the Linux side (think suckless) and TW is the only community that doesn't care for labels, but just the best solution.
what could we do better? prompts for thi:
The styling needs a revamp. The standard font sizes are a good indicator of that, especially on tabs. I think this change must come from the project itself.

The website should have its structure reconsidered and probably show less info upfront. We need new users.

I'm wary of a gradual split in the ecosystem (core+plugin devs) between single-file and Node.

The standard distribution should be more featureful e.g. by shipping some plugins along w/ the core, which means supporting them too.
with your consent, we would like to publ: Yes, I am happy for my responses to be published
